respondent.name: KIM T. THOMAS, INTERIM COMMISSIONER, ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 10-63, Maples v. Thomas. Mr. Garre.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You talk about the State's role.  I assume that you're talking about there is the failure to take action after the return of theAlderson Reporting Company notices.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, put -- putting that -- that to one side, what if only one of the three notices had been returned?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who says so?  Who says so? Who says that they rely on -- you have a local attorney, and you have to have a local attorney for the case,Alderson Reporting Company don't you?  And -- and you want us to believe that the local attorney is -- has no responsibility for the case at all?  Is this really what the -- what the law requires?  I -- I think there is a serious ethical obligation when he has the -- when he gets the notice. He is one of the attorneys for your client.  And he got the notice, right?  That one was not returned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He failed to check with -- with the New York lawyers who were working with him. Why is it -- why is the State responsible for that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Disclaimed to who?  To -- I mean, how could a clerk be expected to know that the local counsel really isn't taking any part?  I mean -- so was the disclaimer to the clerk?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, who says that, Mr. Garre?  I mean, is there anything in the record on that point, on the Alabama system generally?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're begging the question, which is how is the clerk supposed to know this?  This is a functionary in the clerk's office who sends out notices, receives back mail that's not returned.  There has to be some local counsel that does work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How is he supposed to know the difference between those that do and those that don't?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But, you know, even if local counsel is as you -- as you describe it, and nothing in the record establishes it, even if he is a functionary, surely the function would include when he gets a notice, that he makes sure that the -- the people who do the real work know about the notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He didn't perform that function.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But he didn't have a mail drop?  I just didn't hear what you said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: To whom did he make that clear?  You said he made it clear at the outset.  To whom?  And where is that in the record?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: His affidavit after -- after the fact, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did -- did he tell the clerk of the court that that was the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, you know, I'm counsel of record.  He's the counsel of record, right?  I'm counsel of record, but I don't even do so much as to forward notices to the guys that are doing the real work?  Did he tell the clerk that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's extraordinary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You said that even before that.  In the rule -- you said the Rule 32 -- didn't you say something about -- the -- the notice that went from the prosecutor to Maples did not go to the local counsel, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did the -- did the prosecutor -- I'm not talking about the clerk now.  The prosecutor had a filing in connection with the Rule 32 motion.  Did the prosecutor send that to, well, everybody?  Maples and everybody?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you seem not to rely on what the State as prosecutor did.  It seemed to me the State as prosecutor was recognizing that Maples had no counsel; therefore, sent -- said you'd better file your habeas; this is how much time you have -- sent it just to him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where does the Constitution say, by the way, that you have to give notice, that every judicial action has to be noticed --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- to the parties to the case?  The Federal rules don't -- don't require notice, do they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the Federal rules don't say it.  You don't have to give notice in the Federal rules, do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Capital cases are different?  If you're going to go to jail for life you -- you don't get notice, but if -- if it's a capital case --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, I mean, it's either a rule for all criminal cases or it's not a rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And if -- if it's a rule for all criminal cases, the Federal rules are unconstitutional, you're saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Once you're in court and you have a lawyer, it's up to your lawyer to follow what goes on in the court.  That's the assumption of the Federal rules.  And it seems to me a perfectly reasonable assumption.  And I'm not about to hold thatAlderson Reporting Company -- that they are unconstitutional simply because an extraordinary requirement of notice, which is not required by the Constitution, has gone awry.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if -- but -- your case it seems to me turns critically on Butler's role.  How much, in addition to what he did or didn't do, would he have to do to put him in a position where he was in fact representing Maples in your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Where do we look -- where do we look to see that it's standard practice for local counsel throughout the country to contact out-of-State counsel when something like this is received?  I remember a case from the Federal system in which local counsel appeared and did exactly what was done here, moved the admission of an out-of-State criminal defense attorney, who then tried the case for a year, got sick, and the judge said to the local -- local counsel:  Come on in; you're going to take over this trial and try it for the next 6 months.  And the local counsel said: Whoa, I only signed up to move the admission of this fellow.  The judge said:  That's too bad; you're counsel of record, and you have to take over the case. I don't understand that what is alleged to have occurred here is that far out of the ordinary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He can't define his role as a lawyer.  Once he appears before a court and says, I am counsel of record, he has certain responsibilities. It's not up to him to say what his responsibilities are.Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And if they don't extend even to forwarding notice, even to making sure that the people who were doing the legwork in the case know that -- that the clock is running, my goodness, I can't imagine what his responsibility is.  It's not up to him to define it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Before you get to the court, could I ask you about what the State attorney, the prosecuting attorney, knew?  Did the prosecuting attorney know that these two individuals from New York were representing this person?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  So you think you have -- in your view, the counsel of record knew that these two people in New York were part of the representation.  Did the counsel -- I mean, not the counsel of record; the counsel for the State. Did the counsel know that they hadn't gotten the notice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there any reason to think that the State attorney or whoever was prosecuting thought that the local counsel was likely not to do much?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes?  Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Now, so it'sAlderson Reporting Company possible -- we'll find out later -- that the State -- the prosecuting attorney who works for the State knew all those things:  One, he's represented by counsel in New York; two, they didn't get the notice; three, the local attorney isn't going to do anything; and conclusion:  They likely knew he didn't get the notice, but they are asserting that this is an adequate State ground to bar him coming into habeas; is that the correct posture of the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, all we have to decide is whether under these circumstances the State attorney's knowledge of all those facts mean that the State cannot assert this is an adequate State ground.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do we know that he knew all of those facts?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, we don't know that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let me ask you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, can I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let me ask you this, if I may.  I don't know if -- I don't think the briefs covered it.  It may be in there.  Do you know, in Alabama and/or nationwide, in how many capital cases there is no appeal?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if -- the New York lawyers did not abandon Mr. Maples prior to the time that they left their law firm in New York, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, their conduct prior to that time would be attributed to him, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.  Part of their conduct was setting up their arrangement with Mr. Butler where he would show up as counsel of record butAlderson Reporting Company not really do anything.  So, why aren't the consequences of that arrangement attributed to Maples as well?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Garre, can I go back to Justice Kennedy's question?  This was not an appeal. The question was how many capital cases is there no appeal.  He had been convicted and had appealed, right? The -- this is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The direct proceedings were over.  He had appealed up to -- up to the State supreme court.  Did he seek cert here, too?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He did.  And this was a postconviction --Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That may be, but I don't think it's extraordinary that there be no appeal, I mean, postconviction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It can be allowed, but it would not seem to me extraordinary that it not be sought.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, in -- in this -- in this case, there was a direct appeal, and then there was this proceeding that we're talking about here.  The trial judge waited for 18 months.  So, you would think there's some merit to the underlying claim.  Any statistics on whether or not -- on how often an appeal is abandoned or not pursued in this kind of case?  No statistics?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm aware of the allegations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Garre, I have two questions for you.  Is that -- is this State the only one that doesn't appoint counsel in a postconviction capital case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But the vast majority do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In capital cases?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  Number two, I thought there were two questions in this -- in this part of your case.  The first is, don't we have to decide that abandonment, which you have termed, is cause --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- in a -- to excuse a procedural bar in a State court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So we have to decide first whether we extend Holland to this setting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's the due process. I'm talking about -- yes, both we would have to decide. Assuming -- we have to decide the first question.  Is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Will we extend Holland to this type of situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yes, I -- I understand.Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Could we find --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what is the line, Mr. Garre, between abandonment and just plain old negligence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, if this local counsel simply goofed in not -- not advising the people that were doing the legwork in the case, why -- why is that abandonment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Putting aside the question of local counsel, could we find that there was an abandonment if the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell continued to represent Mr. Maples after the two young attorneys left the firm?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And does the record showAlderson Reporting Company that they -- they did not represent Mr. Maples, that this was done purely by the two attorneys?  Is there a finding by a court on that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But in the -- in the practice of a law firm, these were very junior people. Wouldn't the law firm have to have some involvement in giving them permission to provide this representation? I mean, usually there's something like a pro bono committee and a higher level.  Can -- can such junior associates just go ahead and say, we want to spend a lot of our time defending a man on death row?  Wouldn't they have to get some kind of permission?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, what do we know about Mr. De Leeuw's role, Mr. Garre?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Garre, we don't know, we don't know.  Isn't that just proof that if we were to find that Holland applied, a Holland exception applied, that we would have to remand this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In that regard, there is one part of Holland that you don't really address, which is that Holland contrasted a statute of limitations issue with respect to access to a Federal court with aAlderson Reporting Company procedural bar and said that the State's procedural bar had interest of federalism, that we had to be cautious of ignoring a State procedural bar because of federalism.  If we were to extend Holland in the way you want, how do we justify ignoring federalism in that situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Garre --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Could we go back to the state of the record?  You've said a few times, and your brief does, that the record is skimpy on various important matters.  Would you go further and say that the record is irretrievably corrupted, tainted by conflicts of interest?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We do know, though, that they were not counsel of record.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, we know that the two who were listed as counsel of record --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- were not representing him, and they hadn't told the court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But it seems to me it's up to you to produce the facts that would justify our reversing the case that you're asking us to do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you say, well, we don't have these facts; well, send -- send it back so I can -- no, you should have gotten the facts in the first place. If the record doesn't show the things that you need to show to get this case reversed, the case should not be reversed, it seems to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When did you first make the abandonment claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When was it?  Wasn't it first made in the -- in the request for rehearing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's rather late.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That isn't abandonment. That isn't abandonment.  The attorneys' actions established cause; that does not mean abandonment to me.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Garre. Mr. Neiman.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Let's say the three notices are sent out; all three of them come back, okay? Let's even go further and say the prosecutor knows that nobody representing Mr. Maples received notice.  What happens then?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yeah, I know it would be more substantial.  That's why -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: My question is what happens?  Are you prepared to acknowledge that in that case, Mr. Maples had been abandoned by all of his lawyers, it was known to the prosecution, and, therefore, the failure to file the notice should not constitute an adequate and independent State ground barring collateral relief?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What does the return mean when you get -- get a notice returned?  It just said no longer at Sullivan & Cromwell, is what the two of them said, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Does that necessarily mean that they've abandoned the case?  It just means you got the wrong address, doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't that the only thing it means for sure, these lawyers are no longer here at Sullivan & Cromwell?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know how that would be an indication of abandonment.  Can't you switch a law firm and keep the client?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Neiman, I think we're blurring two issues.  We're not talking about abandonment in this respect.  We're talking about noticeAlderson Reporting Company going to no one, and a -- and a clock ticking from a certain date that no one knows about. I mean, they were preparing for a hearing before this judge.  So they weren't anticipating that he was going to rule without anything further.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But as far as -- as far the record shows, De Leeuw is not on the record at all. There were three counsel of record.  Two of them -- well, let's go back to this -- this -- the first issue. The State by its own conduct showed it didn't regard Butler as any kind of representative, because it didn't even send its Rule 32 response to Butler; isn't that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the notice that he's -- he had lost in the Alabama court and he'd better, if he wants to go to the Federal court, do something about it?  That notice went only to Maples, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And Mr. Garre made the point that if Maples were represented, that that would be improper, to -- to send a notice to Maples alone. So, the -- so, the State's attorney must have thought that Maples had been abandoned by his lawyers because he didn't notify any of them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, he didn't have to send the letter.  That letter had no legal effect,Alderson Reporting Company did it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, it was just:  By the way, your time has expired.  I mean, this is not -- what could the lawyer do about it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It wasn't a required notice that he had to give to the lawyer or to anybody else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So he just made this extraneous, volunteered statement to Maples instead of to his lawyer.  I don't -- I don't know what that proves.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why did he do it? Why did he do it, then?  Just gloating that -- that the fellow had lost? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What was the point of it?  He must have thought there was a problem, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is that surprising?  I think Justice Kennedy asked your adversary:  How often do appeals lie from the denial of State postconviction remedies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In a capital case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Particularly in a -- in a capital case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I just have two questions going back to the very beginning, when we were talking about the misaddressed or the unreceived mail.  When the notices come back "no longer at Sullivan & Cromwell," that's just as if it said, functionally, don't you think, "wrong address"?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, it's pretty clear that they didn't get their -- get the mail, get the letter, because it's sent back.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: One other thing while I'm talking with you, and it's a tangential point, perhaps. Could the State of Alabama under your laws waive what you allege to be the procedural default?  If you thought there was substantial merit to the underlying claims, even though you take the position that they ultimately should be rejected, could you have simply waived the procedural default and allowed the appeal to proceed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Has Alabama ever waived lack of timely appeal in a capital case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, could we go back to the Chief Justice's initial question?  Let's assume the two letters went to Sullivan & Cromwell and came back "left firm," as they did, and that the letter to Butler came back "deceased."  Would there be cause in that situation to excuse the State's procedural ground?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, we -- we know that they -- that both lawyers in this case didn't move to another firm.  Both of them took jobs that precluded them from representing this defendant.  So, I don't know how I define abandonment other than I take a job where I can't work for you anymore.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, you accept -- I don't mean to interfere with the question, but -- so, you accept the idea that there is a distinction between malfeasance and abandonment.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.  So, then the only thing -- the only thing we're talking about is whether, on these particular facts, there has been abandonment or not.  Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: From your perspective.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But we do know they weren't counsel of record.  We do know that the only two counsel of record were no longer representing him, and he had no reason to know that they weren't, but they were not -- they couldn't represent him. The two -- the only two out-of-town counsel were the two who disabled themselves from representing him by taking other jobs.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, there was no one from Sullivan & Cromwell other than those two on the record. So, on the record, they had abandoned him, and there was no substitute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, the argument is that on the record or not is determinative for the out-of- town counsel, but it is not determinative for the in-town counsel.  The fact that he is counsel of record doesn't count, but the fact that those two are does count.  And only when you combine those two does the man have no counsel.  Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: The notice inquiry is supposed to be a pragmatic one.  As far back as Mullane, we've said that the question that we're supposed to ask ourselves is:  Is this what somebody would do if they actually wanted to accomplish notice, if they actually wanted the person to get that letter?  So, I'm justAlderson Reporting Company going to ask you, General, if you were a lawyer in an important litigation and you send off an important letter to two lawyers, your principal adversaries, as well as to a local counsel who you think may not be involved in the substance of the litigation, you don't know for a fact, but you think that there is some substantial likelihood that he's not particularly involved, as local counsel often aren't -- so, you send off this letter and you get it back from the principal attorneys, and you ask yourself:  Huh, should I do anything now? What would you say? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, as then the clerk has to believe that it's an important letter.  Right?  It's not important enough to be required by the Federal rules.  How important is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Justice Scalia is right. I'm assuming that a letter disposing of a -- of a rulingAlderson Reporting Company in a capital case issued after 18 months when nobody knew that that letter was coming, that that's an important letter for a death row person to get.  So, Justice Scalia is right to that effect. So, you get this, and you say, well, you would have.  But that's the question that we have to ask about the clerk as well.  The clerk -- the question for the clerk is, if he had really wanted the person to get notice, what would he have done?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You can see from these questions that the arguments that you're making in this capital case, which is sui generis, are pushing the Court to consider rules that would have far-reaching effect, such as a rule that places upon a clerk of the court a constitutional obligation to serve counsel with important documents in the case similar to the constitutional obligation to serve initial process in the case.  And the question that I would like to ask is whether this -- the -- whether you as the Solicitor General or the Attorney General of Alabama have anAlderson Reporting Company obligation to push this matter in this way.  This is a case where -- as I said, it's a capital case, as we all recognize.  Mr. Maples has lost his right to appeal through no fault of his own, through a series of very unusual and unfortunate circumstances. Now, when his attorneys moved to file an out-of-time appeal, why wouldn't you just consent to that?  If he did not receive an effective assistance of counsel at trial, why not get a decision on the merits on that?  Why push this -- this technical argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There's no --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There's no possibility under Alabama rules for an out-of-time appeal in this circumstance?  No extension?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But is that a discretionary matter or is that a flat rule, once you've passed a certain time deadline, you're out of -- you're out of luck; there's no opportunity where there's good cause for an extension?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, this goes to my earlier question, and continuing Justice Alito's line of questioning.  If the State of Alabama had told the State court, in all of the circumstances, we think there should be an out-of-time appeal granted -- you're -- are you indicating that the State court said, well, that's a good idea, but we can't do it because it's not appropriate in these circumstances?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did you -- did you opposeAlderson Reporting Company it?  Did the State oppose the out-of-time appeal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could the State in -- excuse me.  Could the State in the -- in the Federal litigation have waived the procedural default?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But you agreed with me earlier that abandonment is an exception to the adequate and independent State grounds.  So, under yourAlderson Reporting Company view of the case, Coleman was not necessarily controlling.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: When -- when lawyers stopAlderson Reporting Company representing a client, as the two did, isn't there some obligation of them to tell the client and the court, we're no longer representing you, and arrange for substitutions?  There were never any substitutions on the record of the other counsel.  The record said these two people are representing Maples, and those two weren't.  They never told the court, and they never told Maples.  Isn't there some obligation on -- on their part to the court when they stop representing a client to advise the court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it -- is it -- I'm still unclear on one factual thing.  Did the State's attorneys know that the letters had come back?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Should they have known?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do they check the -- do they check the docket every so often to see what's happened?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why did --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then why did they -- why did they send to Maples alone the notice, you'd better file your Federal habeas?  They didn't send it to those counsel.  Where did they -- what made them send it -- send that notice directly to Maples and not to either of the Sullivan & Cromwell lawyers?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, he had figured out that something had terminated the relationship between Mr. Maples and his lawyers?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, even --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even if you assume that he had figured it out, that -- you would have to impute his knowledge to the clerk of court to -- to find the -- the fault on the part of the State that's alleged here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did he tell the clerk of court that he was only going to send it to Maples?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, could you tell me -- I'm assuming you've practiced in your State for a while.Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How frequent is it in the Alabama capital system that local counsel takes the laboring oar, or even an active participation, in the defense or actions of a capital defendant? Your -- the amici here says generally they did what Mr. Butler did; they just facilitated the -- the admission of the volunteer attorneys.  Was that your experience?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  If we have to send it back, I guess we'd have to say what the rule is. So, what -- what is the rule?  What about a rule that says, where in fact attorneys do abandon the client and the local attorney does as a matter of practice in the State do virtually nothing except to facilitate foreign representation, and where the State had cause to believe -- cause to believe -- that all that was true, then the State cannot assert this as an adequate ground. That's all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Irrespective of what the rules were, you'd have to show -- he would have to show that, in fact, in the State it is a practice such that the local counsel doesn't do much of anything except facilitate, because this is a state of mind as to whether the State -- and the State knows that. If he shows both of those things and shows that the letter came back and shows this was abandonment or close thereto, then the State ought to know that this individual has no idea about filing a piece of paper and thinks somebody else is doing it.  And that's enough to say this is not adequate State ground that would block Federal habeas.  Now, your argument against that is what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It seems in the briefs --Alderson Reporting Company there's certainly a lot in the briefs that seemed to say that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Neiman, am I correct that under the Alabama rules when an attorney is represented by more than one attorney, the notice does not have to go to all of them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It can only go to one, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, as far as local counsel knew, he was the only one to receive notice of this thing, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is it correct or does the notice -- most of the notices I see list the people who have been served.  Were the New York people listed on the notice that went to Butler?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, then he knewAlderson Reporting Company he wasn't the only one getting notice.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Or he knew that he was the only one who was supposed to get notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I guess the problem is, accept the rule; it exists.  But if a lawyer says, I don't care, I'm not going to do whatever the rules required me to do, what more do you need for abandonment? If a lawyer comes in and says, I understand this is a rule of the court; I understand that I'm supposed to do x, y, and z; I don't care; I'm just not -- that's the question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What's the difference between "I don't care" and abandonment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: We're not talking about the notice issue; we are talking about the abandonment question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If we find --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If we find that these lawyers did abandon their client, will there be some sanction imposed upon them by the bar?  I often wonder, just as when we find that there's been inadequate assistance of counsel in a capital case, does -- does anything happen to the counsel who have been inadequate in a capital case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Have you ever heard of anything happening to them?  Other than they're getting another capital case? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You said a few moments ago that Butler did more than your friend suggested.  What more did he do?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, after the default, sure.  But what did he do before?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What did he do more than that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you made a fairly serious suggestion that your friend had not accurately represented what Butler did.  And you still haven't told me one thing he did more than move theAlderson Reporting Company admission of the out-of-town attorneys.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Sure.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Thank you. Mr. Garre, you have 4 minutes remaining. REBUTTAL ARGUMENT BY GREGORY G. GARRE ON BEHALF OF THE PETITIONER

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We don't have to adopt the State's position that he was not abandoned.  We have to adopt your position that he was abandoned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What is troubling to me about the abandonment argument is that -- is the fear that if the Court says that abandonment is cause, there will be many, many cases in which the allegation is:  My attorney wasn't just ineffective and negligent; the attorney was so bad that the attorney in effect abandoned me. And that will substantially change existing law.  Now, how can that be prevented?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, do you know how often Holland relief has been granted -- since it's very recent, but how -- how frequently Holland relief hasAlderson Reporting Company been granted by the courts below?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Garre, how do we distinguish between abandonment and simply a botched, a very botched, transfer of responsibility within a law firm?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Counsel. The case is submitted.
